block.p: Assembly Line to Be Added At Daimler Plant in Alabama DaimlerChrysler plans to announce today that it will nearly double production in Alabama, adding another assembly line close to the site where it already builds Mercedes M-Class sport utility vehicles, auto industry officials and consultants said over the weekend.

Auto industry consultants and auto parts suppliers said that the company would make a so-called crossover vehicle that would combine the features of a minivan and the M-Class sport utility vehicle. [Page C2.]

Assembly Line to Be Added At Daimler Plant in Alabama DaimlerChrysler plans to announce today that it will nearly double production in Alabama, adding another assembly line close to the site where it already builds Mercedes M-Class sport utility vehicles, auto industry officials and consultants said over the weekend.

Auto industry consultants and auto parts suppliers said that the company would make a so-called crossover vehicle that would combine the features of a minivan and the M-Class sport utility vehicle. [Page C2.]

Offer Is Seen for London Exchange OM Gruppen, which runs the Stockholm stock exchange, is expected to make a formal offer, which could include a hostile bid, for the London Stock Exchange, which rejected an informal $1.18 billion offer last week, executives close to the discussions said. [C2.]

A Mayor Backs a Web Business More than 750 local governments use the Web site operated by NetClerk to put the construction-permit process online. But so far, only the mayor of San Francisco, Willie L. Brown, has become part of NetClerk's advertising campaign. Last week, NetClerk put a picture of Mr. Brown and the city's seal on its Web site, www.netclerk.com, along with a letter the mayor had written praising the company for, among other things, helping reduce lines at city hall. [C4.]

Sprint in a Wireless Joint Venture Sprint's wireless unit and the Internet incubator Ecompanies plan to announce a venture today to finance start-up companies in wireless communications. The venture, Ecompanies Wireless, will receive a $15 million investment from Spint's wireless unit, Sprint PCS. [C8.]

Morgan Stanley Revamps Its Ads Morgan Stanley Dean Witter may still measure success one investor at a time, but in a new ad campaign starting this week, its brokerage unit is dropping the slogan it has used for more than a decade and is centering its $150 million advertising budget on a blunter approach. The ads take dead aim at electronic brokerage firms. Advertising. [C11.]
A study to be released today found that a majority of online advertisements had short life spans, running three weeks or less. [C11.]

Windows Software List Scrutinized The ruling against Microsoft said a crucial barrier confronting the company's potential competitors were the 70,000 programs written to run solely on the Windows operating system. But Richard B. McKenzie, an economist, contends that there are probably fewer than 10,000 Windows programs in use today. The lower figure indicates that Microsoft is not the impregnable fortress depicted at its trial, Mr. McKenzie writes in a paper. [C7.]

New Math in MSNBC's Billboards The cable network MSNBC has placed two billboards on the West Side Highway in Manhattan that promote its main nighttime news program and its host, Brian Williams, and boast of 42 million viewers. Executives at some of MSNBC's rivals find the signs a bit annoying because of the large ratings figure, which uses some inventive arithmetic. [C10.]

Auction Uncovers Fissures in Europe Ever since the bidding ended in Germany's auction of new wireless licenses, even devoted market enthusiasts have started to wonder whether this is the way to go. Six companies bid a total $46 billion for licenses. Investors have been dumping shares of the winners, and Standard & Poor's warned that it would probably lower most of the companies' credit ratings. The auction also uncovered an uneven playing field in Europe. New Economy. [C4.]
